children.step: Activate Yeast
Check Yeast Expiry Date

Locate the yeast container. Identify the container by its label, noting the brand (e.g., Fleischmann’s, Red Star), product type (e.g., Active Dry Yeast, Instant Yeast), and size (e.g., 3.3 oz, 5 oz). Ensure the container is resting on a stable, level surface.

Using a calibrated ruler or measuring tape, measure the distance from the bottom of the container to the surface of the yeast itself. Record this measurement in millimeters. Maintain a perpendicular angle to the container's surface during measurement. Ensure the measurement is taken at a point directly in the center of the container’s base.

Visually inspect the yeast. Note its physical appearance. Is it a uniform color (typically beige to light brown)? Is there any visible discoloration (e.g., dark spots, mold)? Is the yeast uniformly granular, or are there clumps? Document any visual anomalies. Take a photograph of the yeast for reference.
Locate the expiry date printed on the container. Using a magnifying glass with a 7x magnification

Compare the measured expiry date to the current date. Using a calendar app or physical calendar, determine the current date. Calculate the difference in days between the current date and the expiry date. Record this difference in days. Round the result to the nearest whole number.
If the difference in days is less than 60 days, the yeast is still within its expiration date. Document this result and the measured expiry date.
If the difference in days is 60 days or more, the yeast is past its expiration date. Document this result and the measured expiry date.

Visually inspect the yeast again, focusing on any signs of degradation that may have become more apparent due to the passage of time. Note any changes in texture, odor (carefully sniff – avoid deep inhalation), or color.

If the yeast exhibits any signs of degradation (e.g., significant discoloration, off-odor, clumping), mark the container with a ‘DO NOT USE’ label, clearly indicating the date of inspection and the observed issues. Photograph the marked container.
Warm Water Preparation

Locate the Water Source: Identify the nearest faucet. Measure the distance from your current position to the faucet using a measuring tape. Record this distance as 'Distance_to_Faucet' (e.g., 3.2 meters). Confirm the faucet is accessible and free from obstructions within a 0.5-meter radius.

Prepare the Pot: Acquire a ceramic pot with a minimum volume of 1.5 liters. Visually inspect the pot for cracks or damage. If any damage is present, discontinue this task and inform a supervisor. Place the pot securely on a stable, level surface.

Retrieve the Measuring Cup: Locate a standard 250 ml measuring cup. Verify the cup is clean and dry. If not, thoroughly wash it with soap and water, ensuring all traces of soap are removed by rinsing with clean, potable water for at least 30 seconds.

Initiate Water Flow: Turn the faucet handle to the 'cold' setting. Adjust the handle until the water flow is a consistent, gentle stream. Do not allow the water flow to be forceful or erratic. Observe the water stream for 5 seconds to ensure stability.

Add Initial Water: Using the 250 ml measuring cup, carefully pour water into the ceramic pot. Begin with 500 ml of water. Monitor the water level within the pot using your eye, ensuring the water does not overflow. Maintain a steady, controlled pouring motion. The pouring speed should be approximately 2.5 seconds per 100 ml.

Temperature Monitoring - Phase 1: Immediately after pouring the initial 500 ml, insert a calibrated thermometer (range: 0-100°C) into the water. Ensure the thermometer bulb is fully submerged. Record the initial water temperature as 'Initial_Temperature' (e.g., 20°C). Hold the thermometer steady for 10 seconds.

Temperature Adjustment - Phase 1: Based on the 'Initial_Temperature', adjust the faucet flow. If the temperature is below 30°C, increase the faucet flow by 20%. If it is above 40°C, decrease the faucet flow by 20%. Maintain the adjusted flow for 5 seconds, continuing to monitor the water temperature using the thermometer.

Add Remaining Water: Using the 250 ml measuring cup, pour 1 liter of water into the ceramic pot. Continue to monitor the water level and temperature during the pouring process. Record the final water temperature as 'Final_Temperature' (e.g., 35°C).

Final Temperature Confirmation: Allow the water to sit undisturbed for 60 seconds. Re-check the water temperature using the thermometer. Record the final temperature. Verify that the final temperature is within +/- 2°C of the 'Final_Temperature' recorded immediately after pouring the last 1 liter.

Water Source Shut-Off: Carefully turn the faucet handle back to the 'off' position. Ensure the water flow ceases completely. Dispose of any remaining water in the measuring cup according to established waste disposal protocols.
Measure Yeast

Retrieve a sterile 10 ml pipette and a sterile 10 ml pipette bulb from the designated biohazard storage cabinet. Ensure the cabinet door is securely closed and the biohazard warning sign is clearly visible. Take 60 seconds to visually verify the integrity of the pipette bulb – check for any signs of leakage or damage.

Prepare a sterile sample rack with 5 sterile 1 ml microcentrifuge tubes. Using a sterile gloved hand, carefully remove one tube from the rack. Visually inspect the tube for any cracks or damage. Place the tube on a clean, flat laboratory bench. Confirm the bench surface is free of any debris. Maintain a distance of 15 cm between your hands and the tube.

Using the sterile 10 ml pipette, draw 10 ml of sterile phosphate buffered saline (PBS) solution from the designated PBS reservoir. Ensure the reservoir cap is securely closed. Initiate the pipette bulb action: Slowly and steadily depress the bulb for exactly 3 seconds. Maintain consistent pressure throughout the 3 seconds. Observe the liquid rising within the pipette. Stop when the liquid level reaches the 10 ml mark on the pipette’s scale. Do not exceed 10 ml.

Carefully and slowly dispense 1 ml of the PBS solution from the 10 ml pipette into the sterile 1 ml microcentrifuge tube. Begin dispensing from a height of approximately 30 cm above the tube's surface. Maintain a consistent, downward motion. Control the flow rate so that the liquid enters the tube at a rate of approximately 0.5 ml per second. Monitor the liquid level in the pipette. Stop dispensing when the liquid level reaches the 1 ml mark. Do not introduce any air bubbles into the tube during dispensing.

Immediately after dispensing, gently invert the microcentrifuge tube 5 times. Ensure each inversion is a complete rotation of the tube, approximately 180 degrees. Count each inversion clearly in your mind – 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. This mixing step is crucial for proper cell suspension.

Using a sterile pipette aid, accurately measure 100 µl of the yeast suspension from the microcentrifuge tube and transfer it into a new sterile 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube. Maintain a stable visual alignment between the microcentrifuge tube and the receiving tube. This transfer should take no longer than 5 seconds.

Record the exact time of completion for each step of this process, noting the time down to the nearest second. Maintain a logbook entry for this measurement, including the date, time, and precise measurement readings.
Seal the 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube with a sterile, tight-fitting cap. Secure the cap by rotating it clockwise until it clicks into place. This confirms a tight seal to prevent contamination.
Place the sealed 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube into a labeled rack and store it at 4°C until analysis.
Add Yeast to Warm Water
Locate a clean glass measuring cup with a volume of 100 milliliters (0.1 liters). Ensure the cup is free of any residue or contaminants. Place the measuring cup on a stable, level surface.

Retrieve 20 milliliters (0.02 liters) of distilled water from its container. Using a clean, calibrated pipette, carefully draw up 20 milliliters of the distilled water. Observe the meniscus at eye level to ensure accurate measurement – the bottom of the meniscus should align with the 20ml mark on the pipette.

Pour the 20 milliliters of distilled water into the 100 milliliter measuring cup. Using a controlled pour, dispense the water from the pipette into the measuring cup. Maintain a steady, consistent stream to minimize splashing or spills. Observe the water level in the cup.

Warm the distilled water to 37 degrees Celsius (98.6 degrees Fahrenheit). Using a thermometer with a digital display, insert the thermometer into the water. Allow the water to sit for 15 seconds. Verify the temperature reading on the thermometer. If the temperature is outside of the 37-38 degree Celsius range, gently agitate the water with a clean stirring rod for 5 seconds to ensure even temperature distribution.

Retrieve one (1) packet of active dry yeast (approximately 7 grams). Carefully open the yeast packet using a clean, dry knife or scissors. Do not use your fingers to minimize contamination. Inspect the yeast for any discoloration or unusual odor. Discard the yeast packet if it appears compromised.

Using a clean spoon, gently scoop 7 grams of active dry yeast from the packet. Use a calibrated digital scale to verify the weight is precisely 7.00 grams. Record the weight precisely before adding to the water.
Slowly sprinkle the 7 grams of active dry yeast into the 37 degrees Celsius water. Use a clean spoon to ensure even distribution. Avoid stirring or agitating the water at this stage.
Gently stir the mixture clockwise with a clean stirring rod for exactly 10 seconds. Use a consistent, slow stirring motion. Do not over-stir. Observe the yeast granules dissolving into the water.

Allow the yeast mixture to stand undisturbed for 5 minutes. Maintain a room temperature of approximately 22-25 degrees Celsius (72-77 degrees Fahrenheit). Do not cover the measuring cup during this time.
Wait for Yeast to Bloom

Locate the Yeast Starter Jar: Identify the glass jar labeled 'Yeast Starter' on the laboratory bench. Ensure the jar is positioned approximately 30 centimeters from the primary light source and 15 centimeters from the edge of the bench to avoid accidental spills.

Prepare the Observation Surface: Place a clean, white ceramic tile – measuring 15 centimeters by 20 centimeters – directly beneath the Yeast Starter Jar. Ensure the tile surface is completely dry. Check for any dust or debris using a magnifying glass and gently wipe with a lint-free cloth.

Activate the Light Source: Turn on the primary light source – a fluorescent lamp – and adjust the height so the light is positioned 75 centimeters above the observation tile. Confirm the light emits a consistent, white light with no noticeable flicker.

Observe Initial Activity: Begin observing the Yeast Starter Jar. Using a digital stopwatch, record the time to the nearest second. Note the initial appearance of the yeast bloom - ideally, a fluffy, white mass extending upwards from the liquid. Document the initial height of this bloom, measured from the surface of the liquid using a calibrated ruler, to the nearest millimeter.
Maintain Constant Observation: Continue observing the Yeast Starter Jar every 30 seconds for the next 5 minutes. Record the time and height of the yeast bloom after each observation period.

Measure Bloom Expansion: During each 30-second observation period, using the calibrated ruler, measure the vertical distance from the surface of the liquid to the highest point of the yeast bloom. Record this distance to the nearest millimeter and note the time of observation.

Record Rate of Bloom: After 10 minutes of observation, calculate the average rate of bloom expansion (millimeters per second) by subtracting the initial height measurement from the final height measurement, dividing by the total time (in seconds), and rounding to two decimal places. Record this rate in a dedicated notebook.

Document Environmental Factors: Record the ambient temperature in the laboratory in Celsius to the nearest degree. Note any other relevant environmental factors, such as airflow or vibration that could potentially influence the yeast bloom.

Photograph the Bloom: At the 10-minute mark, take a high-resolution photograph of the Yeast Starter Jar, ensuring the observation tile and light source are clearly visible in the frame. Use a fixed focus setting and ensure the lighting is consistent with the initial setup.
Combine Dry Ingredients
Gather Dry Ingredients

Locate the dry ingredients container labeled 'All-Purpose Flour' on the countertop. Ensure the container is within 30 centimeters of your right hand.  Observe the container's label for precise measurement markings.

Using your right hand, grasp the container’s lid firmly but gently, applying approximately 5 Newtons of pressure. Rotate the lid clockwise exactly 90 degrees. Maintain this rotation for a duration of 1.5 seconds.

Carefully lift the lid approximately 15 centimeters upwards.  Hold the lid at a 45-degree angle to the countertop for a duration of 0.75 seconds, allowing any spilled flour to naturally fall back into the container.

Using a dedicated measuring scoop (stainless steel, 1/4 cup size), reach into the flour container. Lower the scoop into the flour until the bottom of the scoop is fully submerged.  Maintain this position for 0.3 seconds.  Lift the scoop straight upwards, maintaining a vertical axis.

Carefully scrape the scoop's interior against the inside rim of the container, collecting approximately 30 grams of flour. Observe the flour accumulating on the scoop.  Maintain this motion for 0.5 seconds.

Lift the scoop with the collected flour approximately 20 centimeters above the mixing bowl.  Hold the scoop motionless for 0.2 seconds.  Release the scoop and gently deposit the flour into the mixing bowl.  Ensure the entire measured amount is within the bowl.
Repeat steps 3-6 to measure and add another 30 grams of flour to the mixing bowl.  Maintain a consistent pace of 0.5 seconds per scoop.
Locate the container labeled 'Granulated Sugar'.  Bring the container to a position 25 centimeters from your left hand.  Observe the markings on the container.
Using a dedicated measuring scoop (stainless steel, 1/2 cup size), repeat steps 3-6, collecting and depositing 60 grams of granulated sugar into the mixing bowl.
Locate the container labeled 'Baking Soda'. Bring the container to a position 40 centimeters from your right hand. Observe the markings.
Using a dedicated measuring scoop (stainless steel, 1 teaspoon size), repeat steps 3-6, collecting and depositing 5 grams of baking soda into the mixing bowl. Maintain a 0.5-second motion.
Assess Ingredient Quality

1. Initial Observation (30 seconds): Approach the container holding the ingredient. Using a standard ruler, measure the distance from your dominant hand to the container’s edge, recording this distance precisely (e.g., 23.7 cm). Observe the ingredient's overall appearance – note color variations, any visible debris, and the general texture. Record a detailed description of these observations in a dedicated notebook, including a photograph using a camera with a 12MP sensor and a fixed focal length of 50mm. Ensure consistent lighting for the photograph (approximately 500 lux).

2. Visual Inspection - Particle Size (2 minutes): Using a magnifying glass with a magnification of 10x, select 10 distinct, randomly chosen particles from the ingredient’s surface. For each particle, measure its diameter using the magnifying glass’s built-in measurement markings (if available). If markings are unavailable, use a digital caliper with a 0.01mm resolution to measure the diameter at its widest point. Record each diameter measurement in millimeters, including a unit indicator. Note any significant variations in particle size.

3. Aroma Assessment (1 minute): Holding the container approximately 15 cm from your nose, inhale deeply for 5 seconds. Immediately upon stopping inhalation, rate the intensity of the aroma on a scale of 1 to 10 (1 being faint, 10 being overwhelmingly strong). Note any specific scents identified (e.g., fruity, earthy, floral, musty) in the notebook. Maintain a consistent breathing pattern throughout this assessment. Use a handheld digital thermometer to record the ambient temperature – this may influence aroma perception; record the temperature in degrees Celsius.

4. Texture Evaluation - Tactile Assessment (3 minutes): Using a clean, sterile spatula, carefully scoop 5 grams of the ingredient. Transfer this sample to a small, clean ceramic dish. Using your fingertips (ensure hands are thoroughly washed and dried), gently roll the ingredient across the ceramic dish for 30 seconds. Evaluate the texture, noting its consistency – is it granular, powdery, smooth, sticky, or something else. Rate the texture on a scale of 1 to 10 (1 being very coarse, 10 being exceptionally smooth). Describe the tactile sensation in detail, including any resistance or slipperiness.

5. Weight Verification (1 minute): Using a digital scale with a precision of 0.1g, weigh the ingredient sample. Record the weight in grams, including the unit indicator. Compare this weight to the expected weight (as indicated on the container’s label, if available). Note any discrepancies. Ensure the scale is level before commencing the measurement.

6. Color Measurement - Spectrophotometer (2 minutes): Using a calibrated spectrophotometer (set to measure reflectance), take three readings of the ingredient's color. Position the spectrophotometer's measurement head 1 cm away from the ingredient’s surface. Record each reading in RGB values (Red, Green, Blue) and in CIE Lab values. Maintain a consistent distance and angle during each reading. Document the spectrophotometer model and calibration date.

7. Visual Inspection - Foreign Material (2 minutes): Using a bright LED flashlight and a magnifying glass (10x), carefully examine the entire surface of the ingredient, moving slowly and methodically. Look for any foreign material, such as insects, dirt, or other contaminants. If any foreign material is observed, document its precise location and size (using the magnifying glass’s measurements) in the notebook. Take a photograph of the foreign material using the same camera settings as in Step 6.

8. Temperature Measurement - Direct Contact (30 seconds): Using a digital thermometer with a probe, insert the probe directly into the ingredient, ensuring complete contact. Record the temperature in degrees Celsius. Allow the probe to remain in contact for 10 seconds to ensure accurate reading. Note the ambient temperature at the time of measurement.
Sift Dry Ingredients

Locate the dry ingredients: Flour (250 grams), Baking Powder (10 grams), and Salt (5 grams) are to be used. Ensure all containers are within easy reach on a clean, flat workspace – a countertop is recommended. The workspace should be free of any distractions and adequately lit.

Prepare the Measuring Cup: Retrieve a dry measuring cup that is clearly labeled for ‘250 grams’ of flour. Ensure the cup is clean and dry. Place the cup on the workspace surface. Orient the cup so the markings are facing upwards.

Scoop the Flour: Using a straight-edged spatula, gently scoop the flour from the container. Scoop in a circular motion, covering the entire top surface of the measuring cup. Do not compress the flour; aim for a loose, airy scoop.
Level the Flour: Using the spatula

Transfer the Flour: Carefully lift the measuring cup with the leveled flour. Holding the cup steady with one hand, smoothly transfer the flour into a separate, clean bowl. Do this in one continuous motion to avoid spilling.

Repeat Measuring and Transfer (Baking Powder): Retrieve a small dry measuring spoon (1 tablespoon or approximately 10 grams). Using the spoon, scoop precisely 10 grams of baking powder from the container.  Verify the measurement against the markings on the spoon. Transfer the baking powder to the same bowl as the flour, ensuring it is gently incorporated.
Repeat Measuring and Transfer (Salt): Retrieve a small dry measuring spoon (1/2 teaspoon or approximately 5 grams). Using the spoon

Final Visual Inspection: Visually inspect the bowl of dry ingredients. Confirm that the flour, baking powder, and salt are evenly distributed and that there are no clumps. If any clumps are present, gently break them up with a clean spatula.  The final volume in the bowl should be approximately 265 grams (flour), 10 grams (baking powder), and 5 grams (salt).

Clean Up: Wipe down the workspace surface with a damp cloth. Return all containers and measuring tools to their original storage locations. Dispose of any excess ingredients according to local regulations.”
Ensure No Foreign Objects

Locate the designated inspection area. This area is defined as a rectangular zone 1.5 meters long, 1.2 meters wide, and 2.1 meters high, starting at the north edge of the workbench and extending east for 1.5 meters. Verify this location using a laser distance measurer, confirming the dimensions to within +/- 1mm.

Don appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE): Wear nitrile gloves, safety glasses with side shields, and a disposable Tyvek coverall. Ensure the Tyvek coverall is properly secured with Velcro closures, with the hood extending at least 15cm over the head and 30cm down the front of the torso.

Using a sterile 10cm x 10cm clear plastic sheet, extend the sheet outwards from the center of the inspection area, creating a circular exclusion zone with a radius of 0.75 meters. Maintain the sheet’s surface level, adjusting its position using small, controlled pushes with the fingertips (no more than 5mm force). Observe the sheet's surface with a flashlight to ensure no debris is visible before the next step.

Employ a handheld, battery-powered LED flashlight with adjustable beam focus (narrowest setting - 3mm). Systematically scan the entire exclusion zone, moving the flashlight in a spiral pattern, starting from the center and moving outwards. Maintain a consistent scanning distance of 1 meter. Record the precise coordinates (X, Y, Z) of any visual anomalies (e.g., dust, debris, foreign objects) observed using a handheld digital coordinate measurement tool, with accuracy to within +/- 2mm.

If a foreign object is identified within the exclusion zone, immediately stop scanning. Note the object's dimensions (length, width, height) using a calibrated ruler, recording the measurements to the nearest 0.1mm. Document the object's color and texture using a visual color chart, selecting the closest match. Take a high-resolution photograph of the object and the surrounding area using a camera with a fixed focal length of 50mm.

Using a sterile swab (7cm x 7cm, lint-free) and 70% isopropyl alcohol, carefully clean the area immediately surrounding the foreign object to a radius of 5cm. Apply the alcohol in short, controlled strokes, avoiding excessive rubbing. Ensure the alcohol evaporates completely before proceeding, verifying this visually with the LED flashlight.

Repeat steps 3 and 4 (scanning with the flashlight and measuring) within a 10cm radius of the cleaned area, to confirm that the cleaning process has eliminated any trace of the foreign object. Document any residual contamination observed.

If, after two iterations of scanning and measurement, no foreign object remains within the designated exclusion zone, proceed to the next inspection area. If contamination persists, repeat steps 3-6 at each iteration, adjusting cleaning technique as needed (e.g., slightly altering the angle of the swab).

Upon completion of the inspection area, remove and properly dispose of all PPE according to established protocols. Sanitize all tools and equipment used during the inspection process with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Transfer to Mixing Bowl

Stand upright, maintaining a neutral posture. Ensure your weight is evenly distributed across both feet, with your knees slightly bent at approximately 15 degrees. Maintain a vertical alignment of your torso, avoiding any leaning or twisting.

Extend your right arm fully, reaching towards the mixing bowl. The tip of your right index finger should be approximately 30 centimeters above the rim of the mixing bowl. Maintain a 90-degree angle at the elbow. Hold your arm steady, avoiding any involuntary tremors.

Slowly lower your right hand towards the mixing bowl. Begin lowering your hand at a rate of approximately 2 centimeters per second. Maintain the 90-degree angle at the elbow throughout the descent. Monitor the position of your hand with your eyes, ensuring the index finger remains aligned with the rim.

As your right hand approaches the rim of the mixing bowl, reduce the descent speed to approximately 1 centimeter per second.  At a distance of 5 centimeters from the rim, pause momentarily for 0.5 seconds to ensure precise alignment.

With your right index finger precisely touching the rim of the mixing bowl, gently rotate your right hand clockwise by 15 degrees. Maintain a slight downward pressure with your index finger to establish contact. The rotation should be smooth and controlled, taking approximately 0.75 seconds to complete.

Maintain the contact between your right index finger and the rim of the mixing bowl.  Do not lift or move your hand.  Maintain the 90-degree angle at the elbow and the 15-degree knee bend. Hold this position for 2 seconds.

Slowly lift your right hand upwards, returning to the starting position.  Raise your hand at a rate of approximately 2 centimeters per second. Maintain the 90-degree angle at the elbow and the 15-degree knee bend throughout the ascent. Avoid any abrupt movements.
Once your right hand is back in the starting position, release your grip on the mixing bowl. Ensure your hand is completely relaxed.
Add Wet Ingredients
Determine Wet Ingredient Quantities

Locate the measuring cup – a standard 1-cup measuring cup, preferably stainless steel, with clear, easily readable markings in ounces and milliliters. Ensure the cup is clean and dry. Place the cup precisely 12 inches from the edge of the countertop, centered along a direct line extending from the countertop’s edge to the wall.

Using a ruler, measure 3.5 inches along the side of the measuring cup, starting from the base of the cup where it meets the handle. Mark this point with a precise, dark-colored permanent marker, applying only a single, thin line. The marker should not extend beyond the cup's rim.

Carefully pour 1/2 cup of water into the measuring cup, ensuring the water level reaches the 1/2 mark on the cup’s perimeter. Verify the water level aligns perfectly with the marked 1/2 cup indicator. Use a level surface for pouring.

Using a small, calibrated syringe (1ml increment), precisely add 3 milliliters of water to the cup. Insert the syringe into the water, ensuring the nozzle is fully submerged. Slowly depress the plunger until 3ml of water is dispensed into the cup. Observe the water level visually and confirm its position aligns with the 1/2 cup measurement.

Using a standard kitchen scale, weigh the water within the measuring cup. Tare the scale to 0.00 grams. Record the weight precisely to the nearest 0.01 gram. The weight should match the volume obtained in the previous steps within a tolerance of +/- 0.02 grams.

Repeat steps 1-5 for each distinct wet ingredient you need to measure. Maintain a consistent distance (12 inches) for the measuring cup placement in each step. Record each ingredient's measurement, including its name, volume in ounces, and volume in milliliters, along with its weight in grams.

After completing all measurements, carefully remove the measuring cup from the countertop. Rinse the cup thoroughly with warm water and dry it completely with a lint-free microfiber cloth. Inspect the cup for any residual water or fingerprints.
For each ingredient, note the total volume of water measured in ounces, milliliters, and grams. This represents the determined wet ingredient quantity.
Prepare Wet Ingredients (e.g., soften butter, whisk eggs)

Retrieve Butter: Reach for the refrigerator. Open the refrigerator door fully, approximately 180 degrees. Extend your right hand and grasp the butter container, a standard 8-ounce (227g) stick of unsalted butter. Ensure a firm, but gentle grip. Close the refrigerator door fully, returning it to its closed position.

Pre-Softening (Phase 1): Place the butter container on a clean, stable cutting board. Using your left hand, hold the cutting board steady. With your right hand, using a butter knife, carefully insert the knife blade approximately 1 inch (2.54 cm) into the center of the butter block. Rotate the knife clockwise, applying consistent downward pressure of approximately 5 lbs (2.27 kg), for precisely 15 seconds. Observe the butter's texture; it should begin to exhibit a slightly yielding consistency.

Pre-Softening (Phase 2): Remove the butter knife. Using your left hand, rotate the cutting board 90 degrees clockwise. With your right hand, using the same butter knife, repeat the insertion and rotation process as in Phase 1, maintaining a consistent downward pressure of 5 lbs (2.27 kg) for exactly 15 seconds. Observe the butter's texture; it should now have a noticeably softer consistency, with slight give upon gentle pressure.

Retrieve Eggs: Reach for the refrigerator. Open the refrigerator door fully, approximately 180 degrees. Extend your right hand and grasp a carton of large eggs (1 dozen, approximately 6.18 ounces or 178g). Gently remove the carton from the refrigerator. Close the refrigerator door fully, returning it to its closed position.

Crack Eggs (Egg 1): Place the egg carton on a clean countertop. Using your left hand, stabilize the carton. With your right hand, grasp the egg by the wide end, avoiding contact with the pointed end. Position the egg directly over a small, clean bowl (approximately 1 cup or 240ml volume). Using a gentle, controlled motion, tap the egg sharply on a stable surface (e.g., a countertop edge) precisely three times. Immediately, using your right thumb and forefinger, gently roll the egg, applying continuous, even pressure, for a duration of 2 seconds. Observe the crack forming along the eggshell. Empty the egg into the bowl, ensuring no shell fragments enter the bowl. Measure approximately 2 tablespoons (30ml) of egg yolk and white into the bowl. Wipe the eggshell clean with a paper towel.

Crack Eggs (Egg 2): Repeat the cracking process from Step 6, using a fresh egg from the carton. Ensure the egg is handled with the same care and precision, following the same timing and pressure guidelines. Measure approximately 2 tablespoons (30ml) of egg yolk and white into the bowl. Wipe the eggshell clean with a paper towel.
Repeat Step 8 for the remaining eggs until all 12 eggs have been cracked and measured into the bowl. Ensure each egg is cracked and measured with the same care and precision.

Whisking (Initial): Using a whisk, place the whisk directly into the bowl containing the measured egg mixture. Begin whisking in a figure-eight motion, covering the entire surface of the mixture. Maintain a consistent speed, approximately 50 strokes per second, for 5 seconds. Observe the mixture becoming slightly lighter in color and volume.

Whisking (Continued): Continue whisking the egg mixture, maintaining the same speed and motion, for a total duration of 30 seconds. Periodically check the mixture's texture, ensuring it remains smooth and homogenous. If necessary, adjust the whisking speed slightly to maintain consistency.
Measure Wet Ingredients Accurately
Locate the primary measuring cup – a standard 1-cup (237 ml) liquid measuring cup with clear, easily readable markings. Ensure the cup is clean and dry before commencing.

Position the measuring cup on a flat, stable surface. Verify the bottom of the cup is level with the surface. Use a small spirit level if available; otherwise, visually assess alignment with a straight edge.

Using a dry measuring spoon set (typically 1/4 cup or 60 ml), carefully scoop out a quantity of the ingredient – for example, 1/4 cup of water.  Do not pack the ingredient; allow it to flow freely into the spoon.

Slowly and steadily pour the measured ingredient from the spoon into the center of the 1-cup measuring cup, maintaining a consistent flow rate. Avoid splashing or dribbling. Aim for a smooth, controlled pour.

Stop pouring precisely when the ingredient level reaches the 1-cup (237 ml) mark on the measuring cup. Observe the meniscus—the curve of the liquid—and read the measurement at exactly the bottom of the meniscus. Maintain eye level with the mark.

If measuring a liquid with a significantly different viscosity (e.g., honey), use a small, clean spoon to carefully transfer a measured amount from the original container to the measuring cup.  Do not pour directly, as this will introduce air bubbles and inaccuracies.

Confirm the measurement by visually comparing the meniscus to the 1-cup mark. Hold your hand vertically, aligning your fingers with the curve of the liquid to accurately gauge the volume. Repeat the check twice.

If the ingredient is a viscous liquid and pouring proves difficult, use a syringe or pipette to draw out a precise volume of the liquid. Calibrate the syringe to the appropriate scale based on the ingredient’s density (consult a reference table if necessary).
After pouring, immediately wipe the exterior of the measuring cup with a clean, dry paper towel to remove any drips or residue. This ensures accurate readings in subsequent measurements.

Record the precise volume of the measured ingredient, including the specific ingredient and the measured quantity (e.g., '1 cup (237 ml) of water'). Note the date and time of measurement for traceability.
Combine Wet Ingredients in Bowl

Locate the Mixing Bowl: Identify a standard 1-quart (946 ml) stainless steel mixing bowl. Ensure the bowl is clean and dry. Place the bowl on a stable, level surface. Verify the surface is free of any obstructions within a 15 cm radius.

Retrieve Liquid 1: Measure 120 ml of Milk. Using a graduated measuring cup with 30 ml increments, pour milk from a refrigerated carton into the mixing bowl. Stop pouring precisely at the 120 ml mark. Maintain a vertical pouring angle of 30 degrees relative to the bowl's rim. Observe the milk level to confirm accuracy. Ensure no drips occur.

Retrieve Liquid 2: Measure 60 ml of Honey. Using a separate, clean 30 ml graduated measuring cup, pour honey from a jar into the mixing bowl. Start pouring from a height of 10 cm above the bowl's surface. Maintain the same 30-degree pouring angle as before. Stop pouring precisely at the 60 ml mark. Observe the honey level to confirm accuracy. Gently swirl the honey to fully incorporate it into the milk.

Retrieve Liquid 3: Measure 30 ml of Yogurt. Using a clean 30 ml measuring spoon, scoop yogurt from a refrigerated container into the mixing bowl. Starting with the spoon approximately 5 cm above the bowl's surface, pour the yogurt slowly and steadily. Observe the yogurt level to ensure it reaches the 30 ml mark. Do not overfill. Gently tap the bowl on the counter surface three times to ensure the yogurt is fully incorporated.

Visual Inspection: Rotate the bowl 180 degrees clockwise. Inspect the mixture for complete integration. Observe for a homogenous color and consistency. Estimate the presence of any streaks or unmixed components. If streaks are present, gently stir with a rubber spatula, applying a circular motion starting from the center of the bowl, for 5 seconds.

Final Stir: Using a rubber spatula, gently stir the mixture in a figure-eight motion for 8 seconds. Maintain a speed of approximately 2 rotations per second. Ensure the bottom and sides of the bowl are thoroughly mixed. The mixture should appear uniform in color and texture.
Bowl Orientation: Rotate the bowl 90 degrees counter-clockwise. Visually inspect the mixture one final time for any remaining inconsistencies. Confirm the mixture is homogenous.
Covering: Place a clean, dry bowl cover over the mixing bowl. Ensure the cover fits snugly but without pressing down forcefully. The cover should be centered on the bowl's surface.
Mix Dough
Prepare Mixing Bowl

Locate the mixing bowl. Identify the bowl; it must be a standard stainless steel mixing bowl, approximately 2.25 quarts in volume, with a smooth interior surface and a tightly fitting lid. Place the bowl on a stable, clean countertop surface. Ensure the countertop is level, using a level if available, to a tolerance of +/- 0.5 degrees.

Retrieve a silicone spatula. Select a silicone spatula, approximately 12 inches in length, with a blade width of 2.5 inches. Ensure the spatula is free of cracks, tears, or any foreign debris. Place the spatula next to the mixing bowl, within 6 inches of the bowl's edge.

Measure 1.5 tablespoons of granulated sugar. Using a standard measuring spoon, scoop 1.5 tablespoons of granulated sugar from the sugar container. Ensure the container is positioned directly above the measuring spoon. Verify that the entire measurement is transferred to the spoon before proceeding.

Position the sugar into the mixing bowl. Carefully slide the measured 1.5 tablespoons of granulated sugar from the measuring spoon into the center of the mixing bowl. Gently tap the spoon against the rim of the bowl three times to ensure all sugar transfers.

Retrieve a damp microfiber cloth. Obtain a clean, dry microfiber cloth. Dampen the cloth with distilled water, ensuring the cloth is only slightly moistened; approximately 50% water, 50% cloth. Wring out any excess water until the cloth is barely damp.

Wipe the interior rim of the mixing bowl. Using the damp microfiber cloth, thoroughly wipe the interior rim of the mixing bowl, moving the cloth in a circular motion for 30 seconds, covering the entire perimeter of the rim. Ensure the rim is completely dry before the next step.
Retrieve a dry microfiber cloth. Obtain a clean, dry microfiber cloth, identical to the previous cloth. Place the cloth on a stable surface.

Dry the interior rim of the mixing bowl. Using the dry microfiber cloth, thoroughly wipe the interior rim of the mixing bowl, moving the cloth in a circular motion for 30 seconds, covering the entire perimeter of the rim. Ensure the rim is completely dry before the next step.
Inspect the mixing bowl. Visually inspect the interior of the mixing bowl for any remaining debris or moisture. If any are present, repeat step 7 until the bowl is completely dry and clean.
Measure Flour Accurately

Locate the measuring cup. Ensure the cup is a standard dry measuring cup, specifically a 1-cup capacity, with clearly marked volume markings in both ounces and milliliters. The cup must be clean and dry, free of any residue.

Place the measuring cup on a flat, stable surface, such as a countertop or cutting board. Ensure the surface is level. Observe the surface for any slight tilt and adjust if necessary, accounting for a maximum deviation of 1/8 inch (3mm).

Using a ruler or measuring tape, measure the distance from the base of the cup to the bottom rim. This measurement must be precisely 3.68 inches (93.5mm). Record this measurement in a notebook or digital device.
With your dominant hand, gently grasp the handle of the measuring cup. Use your index finger to stabilize the cup’s base, applying gentle pressure – no more than 5 pounds of force (22.2 Newtons).

Slowly and steadily, pour dry flour from a container into the cup. Pour continuously for a duration of 5 seconds. Maintain a consistent pouring speed – observe and adjust to ensure the flour enters the cup at a rate of approximately 1/4 inch (6.35mm) per second.
After the 5-second pouring period, immediately pause the pouring motion. Hold your hand steady for 1 second, preventing any further flour from entering the cup.

Using a straight edge (e.g., a ruler or spatula), carefully level off the excess flour along the top rim of the cup. Ensure the level is perfectly horizontal, making contact with the entire circumference of the cup's rim. Observe the flour level, ensuring it does not exceed 3.68 inches (93.5mm).

Visually inspect the flour level. Confirm that the flour line is consistently parallel to the top rim of the cup and that the top of the flour line is exactly 3.68 inches (93.5mm) from the bottom of the cup. Adjust the level with the straight edge if necessary, making small, incremental adjustments of no more than 1/8 inch (3mm) at a time.

Carefully remove the leveled flour from the cup. Place the flour back into the original container, ensuring minimal spillage. Record the precise amount of flour measured in ounces (approximately 1 cup) and milliliters (approximately 237 ml).

Clean the measuring cup thoroughly with warm water and soap. Rinse completely and dry with a lint-free towel. Inspect the cup for any remaining flour residue and remove it with a clean, dry cloth if necessary.
Measure Liquid Ingredients (e.g., milk, water)

Locate the Measuring Cup: Identify a standard, clear plastic measuring cup with markings for milliliters (ml) and ounces (oz). Ensure the cup is clean and dry. Verify the markings are clearly visible and not obscured by any residue.
Determine Liquid Volume Needed: Based on the recipe, note the exact volume of liquid required, specifying whether it’s in milliliters (ml) or ounces (oz). Record this value for future reference.

Position the Measuring Cup: Place the measuring cup on a flat, stable surface, ensuring it's level. Use a small, flat object (e.g., a coin) to check for levelness. Adjust until the bottom of the cup is perfectly horizontal.

Add Initial Liquid (First Pour): Using a clean, dry measuring spoon (typically a tablespoon), add 15ml of the specified liquid (e.g., milk) into the measuring cup. Pour from a height of approximately 30 centimeters above the cup’s rim. Maintain a consistent, steady stream of liquid.

Observe Liquid Level: With your eyes directly aligned with the cup's markings, visually assess the liquid level. Note the current measurement on the markings. Confirm the liquid level is precisely at the 15ml mark.

Adjust Liquid (If Necessary): If the liquid level is not exactly at 15ml, carefully add or remove liquid using the measuring spoon. Add 1ml increments. To add, scoop 1ml of liquid into the cup. To remove, carefully dispense 1ml of liquid back into the original container, ensuring no spillage.

Repeat Adjustments (Until Accurate): Continue adding or removing 1ml increments of liquid until the liquid level aligns precisely with the 15ml mark on the measuring cup. Maintain visual alignment with the markings throughout the process. Record the total number of adjustments made (e.g., 'Added 3ml, Removed 1ml').

Final Volume Check: Once the liquid level is accurately at 15ml, double-check the measurement against a secondary reference, such as a calibrated ruler or another measuring cup. Confirm the accuracy within a tolerance of +/- 0.5ml.
Clean and Store: Immediately clean the measuring cup with warm, soapy water. Rinse thoroughly with clean water and dry with a lint-free towel. Store the measuring cup in a dry, clean location.
Repeat for Subsequent Ingredients: Repeat the entire process for each additional liquid ingredient, meticulously following the same steps and measurements.
Combine Dry Ingredients in Bowl

Locate a medium-sized mixing bowl, preferably stainless steel or glass, with a capacity of approximately 3.5 liters. Ensure the interior surface is completely clean and dry. Visually inspect for any remaining food particles or debris.

Position the mixing bowl centrally on a stable, flat work surface. Confirm the work surface is free from any obstructions or potential hazards. Maintain a 30-degree angle to the bowl for optimal stability. Monitor for any movement or wobble for a duration of 3 seconds.

Retrieve a dry measuring cup with clearly marked volume indicators (cup, tablespoon, teaspoon). Verify the cup's volume markings are aligned with the central axis of the bowl. Confirm the markings are legible and free from smudges or damage.

Using a clean, dry measuring spoon, scoop precisely 120 grams of all-purpose flour into the dry measuring cup. Maintain the spoon level with the rim of the measuring cup. Ensure no flour spills over the cup's rim. Observe the flour level visually; it should not exceed the 120-gram mark on the cup.

Carefully tap the measuring cup firmly on a stable surface (e.g., countertop) three times. This will settle the flour, ensuring an accurate measurement. Hold the cup steady during this process for a duration of 1 second.

Using a clean, dry measuring cup, add precisely 100 grams of granulated sugar into the cup. Using a clean, dry measuring spoon, add the sugar incrementally, ensuring not to overfill the cup. The sugar level should be visually consistent with the 100-gram mark. Observe the sugar level visually; it should not exceed the 100-gram mark.

Repeat the tapping action (three firm taps on a stable surface) to settle the sugar within the cup. Maintain a steady grip for a duration of 1 second. Verify the sugar level is consistent with the 100-gram mark.

Using a clean, dry measuring cup, add precisely 2 teaspoons (approximately 4.2 grams) of baking powder into the cup. Using a clean, dry measuring spoon, add the baking powder incrementally, ensuring not to overfill the cup. The baking powder level should be visually consistent with the 4.2-gram mark.

Repeat the tapping action (three firm taps on a stable surface) to settle the baking powder within the cup. Maintain a steady grip for a duration of 1 second. Verify the baking powder level is consistent with the 4.2-gram mark.

Carefully pour the contents of the dry measuring cup (containing 120 grams of flour, 100 grams of sugar, and 2 teaspoons of baking powder) into the mixing bowl. Ensure a smooth, consistent pour to avoid clumping. Visually confirm the entire content is within the bowl.
Gradually Add Liquid to Dry Ingredients

Locate a mixing bowl, preferably stainless steel, with a capacity of 3.5 liters. Ensure the bowl is clean and dry. Place the bowl on a stable, level surface. Verify the surface is free of any debris or spills.
Position a digital scale directly in the center of the bowl. Ensure the scale is calibrated and set to grams. Confirm the scale is displaying a reading of 0.00g.

Add 250.0g of all-purpose flour to the center of the bowl. Using a spatula, gently spread the flour across the entire surface of the bowl, ensuring there are no pockets of concentrated flour. Maintain a consistent, circular motion with the spatula, covering the entire diameter of the bowl (approximately 23 centimeters).
Await 5 seconds for the flour to fully settle onto the bowl’s surface. Observe visually to confirm a uniform layer of flour is achieved. Do not disturb the flour at this stage.

Add 125.0g of granulated sugar to the center of the bowl. Using the same spatula, spread the sugar evenly across the surface of the flour. Again, maintain a consistent, circular motion, covering the entire diameter of the bowl (approximately 23 centimeters). This should take approximately 3 seconds.

Await 2 seconds for the sugar to fully settle onto the bowl’s surface. Visually inspect the bowl to ensure a uniform distribution of sugar. Make any minor adjustments with the spatula if necessary to eliminate any visible clumps.

Add 10.0g of baking powder to the center of the bowl. Using a clean spoon, gently scoop the baking powder and deposit it in the center. Do not pour. Instead, use the spoon to level the baking powder within the bowl's center. This should take approximately 1 second.

Add 1.0g of salt to the center of the bowl. Using a clean spoon, gently scoop the salt and deposit it in the center of the bowl. Do not pour. Instead, use the spoon to level the salt within the bowl's center. This should take approximately 1 second.

Using a small, clean measuring cup (1/2 cup or approximately 120ml), pour 60.0ml of whole milk into the center of the bowl. Tilt the measuring cup slightly to allow the milk to flow smoothly. Ensure the milk reaches the 1/2 cup mark on the cup before carefully pouring it into the bowl. This should take approximately 2 seconds.

Using the same spatula, gently fold the milk into the dry ingredients. Start in the center of the bowl and gradually work outwards, using a lifting and turning motion with the spatula. Incorporate the milk thoroughly, avoiding overmixing. Continue folding for precisely 10 seconds, maintaining a consistent, gentle motion.
Mix Dough Until Smooth and Elastic

Prepare the Workspace: Clear a 12-inch diameter countertop or work surface. Ensure the surface is completely dry and free of any debris. Place a clean, dry mixing bowl – a 6-quart stainless steel bowl is recommended – directly in the center of the workspace. Position a measuring cup (standard 1-cup size) and a measuring spoon (1-tablespoon size) within easy reach on the countertop.

Combine Dry Ingredients: Add 300 grams (approximately 2 1/4 cups, leveled) of all-purpose flour to the mixing bowl. Using a built-in scale, ensure the flour is precisely measured. Immediately after adding the flour, add 10 grams (approximately 1 teaspoon) of instant dry yeast. Gently level the flour with a straight-edged spatula. Do not stir at this point.

Add Wet Ingredients - Part 1: In a separate measuring container, combine 150 milliliters (approximately 3/4 cup) of lukewarm water – the temperature should be between 105-115°F (40-46°C) – with 10 grams (approximately 1 teaspoon) of salt. Stir gently with a spoon for 5 seconds, ensuring the salt is fully dissolved. Observe the water for clarity.

Combine Wet and Dry Ingredients - Initial Mix: Pour the water-salt mixture into the bowl containing the flour and yeast. Using a sturdy, wooden spoon, begin stirring in a clockwise direction. Maintain a consistent, circular motion. Stir continuously for 30 seconds, increasing the speed of the stirring to approximately 50 rotations per minute. Observe the dough’s consistency – it will initially appear shaggy.

Initial Kneading - First 5 Minutes: Increase the stirring speed to 75 rotations per minute. Continue stirring for 5 minutes. Focus on maintaining even pressure with the spoon. Pay attention to any uneven areas of the dough. If the dough is sticking excessively to the sides of the bowl, add 10 milliliters (approximately 1 teaspoon) of water, one addition at a time, and incorporate it into the dough after each addition. Maintain a consistent stirring action throughout this stage.

Initial Dough Ball Formation: After the initial 5 minutes, the dough should begin to coalesce into a rough ball. Using the bottom of the spoon, gently push the dough from the sides of the bowl towards the center, rotating the bowl by approximately 90 degrees after each push. Repeat this process 6 times, ensuring the entire surface of the dough is being worked. The goal is to create a cohesive, albeit still somewhat sticky, dough mass.

Transition to Hand Kneading - Initial 3 Minutes: Lightly flour a clean, dry work surface (approximately 1/2 cup of all-purpose flour). Turn the dough out onto the floured surface. Begin kneading by lifting the dough with both hands, placing it on the surface, and using the heels of your hands to push the dough away from you in a rhythmic motion. Maintain a consistent pressure – approximately 3-4 pounds. Rotate the dough 90 degrees after every 30 seconds of kneading. Continue kneading for 3 minutes, maintaining a steady pace and consistent pressure.

Continued Kneading - Final 2 Minutes: Increase the kneading pressure to approximately 5-6 pounds. Continue kneading for an additional 2 minutes, focusing on developing the gluten structure. Observe the dough’s elasticity; it should become smoother and more elastic with each rotation. If the dough becomes excessively sticky, add a small amount (approximately 1 tablespoon) of flour at a time, incorporating it fully before adding more. Monitor the dough’s texture, aiming for a smooth, slightly tacky consistency.

Final Dough Assessment: After the total kneading time of 5 minutes, perform a windowpane test. Take a small piece of dough and gently stretch it with your fingers. If it stretches thin enough to see light through it without tearing, the dough is properly kneaded. If it tears easily, continue kneading for another minute, observing the dough's consistency closely. The final dough mass should be smooth, elastic, and cohesive, exhibiting a slight sheen.
First Rise
Prepare Dough Mixture: Combine dry ingredients in a large bowl.

Locate the Large Mixing Bowl: Identify a mixing bowl with a minimum internal diameter of 12 inches (30.48 cm). Confirm the bowl is clean and dry. Place the bowl on a stable, level countertop surface. Ensure there is at least 12 inches (30.48 cm) of clear workspace surrounding the bowl.

Retrieve the Flour: From its storage location (e.g., a flour bin or sealed bag), carefully remove 300 grams (approximately 10.5 ounces) of all-purpose flour. Using a scale, ensure the measurement is accurate to within 1 gram (0.035 ounces).

Measure Salt: Using a dedicated measuring spoon (specifically, a 1-teaspoon measuring spoon), scoop one (1) teaspoon (5.67 grams) of fine table salt. Level the salt with a straight-edged spatula, ensuring no excess salt remains on the spoon.

Measure Baking Soda: Using a separate dedicated measuring spoon (specifically, a 1/2-teaspoon measuring spoon), scoop one (1) half (0.5) teaspoon (2.83 grams) of baking soda. Level the baking soda with a straight-edged spatula, ensuring no excess baking soda remains on the spoon.

Measure Sugar: Using a separate dedicated measuring spoon (specifically, a 1-teaspoon measuring spoon), scoop one (1) teaspoon (4.18 grams) of granulated white sugar. Level the sugar with a straight-edged spatula, ensuring no excess sugar remains on the spoon.

Initial Flour Placement: Gently pour the 300 grams (10.5 ounces) of flour into the center of the large mixing bowl. Do not dump the flour; instead, slowly and steadily pour it from a height of approximately 12 inches (30.48 cm) to minimize flour dust.

Salt Incorporation (Phase 1): Using the straight-edged spatula, lightly scrape the sides and bottom of the bowl, incorporating approximately 75% of the flour into the main mass. Maintain a consistent, circular motion, covering at least 80% of the flour surface area within the bowl.

Salt Incorporation (Phase 2): Using the same straight-edged spatula, gently add the one (1) teaspoon (5.67 grams) of salt. Rotate the bowl slightly, ensuring the salt distributes evenly over the surface. Continue the circular motion described in the previous step for 5 seconds, maintaining constant contact with the flour.

Baking Soda Incorporation: Using the same straight-edged spatula, gently add the one (1/2) teaspoon (2.83 grams) of baking soda. Rotate the bowl slightly, ensuring the baking soda distributes evenly over the surface. Continue the circular motion described in the previous steps for 3 seconds, maintaining constant contact with the flour mixture.

Sugar Incorporation: Using the same straight-edged spatula, gently add the one (1) teaspoon (4.18 grams) of sugar. Rotate the bowl slightly, ensuring the sugar distributes evenly over the surface. Continue the circular motion described in the previous steps for 2 seconds, maintaining constant contact with the flour mixture.
Activate Yeast: Add warm water to the dry ingredients.
Locate the measuring cup designated for 1 cup (237 ml) of liquid. Ensure the cup is clean and dry. Place the measuring cup on a stable, flat surface, preferably a countertop.

Using a clean, dry measuring spoon, scoop exactly 237 ml of warm water from a source of warm water (approximately 40-45°C). The water temperature should be verified using a thermometer, aiming for 42°C.
Carefully pour the measured 237 ml of warm water into the clean, dry measuring cup.

Visually confirm that the water level reaches the 237 ml mark on the measuring cup. If the mark is not visible, adjust the measurement slightly with a clean, dry measuring spoon, adding one milliliter at a time until the mark is achieved.
Locate the container holding the dry yeast ingredients (e.g., active dry yeast, sugar, salt, etc.). Ensure the container is clean and open.

Using a clean, dry spatula, gently scoop approximately 100 grams of the dry yeast mixture from the container. Do not scrape aggressively; instead, gently lift and rotate the spoon to minimize dust exposure.
Carefully pour the 100 grams of the dry yeast mixture into a separate mixing bowl. Maintain a steady stream of pouring to avoid spilling.

Using the same measuring cup containing the 237 ml of warm water, slowly and steadily pour the water into the bowl with the dry yeast mixture. Start pouring from a height of approximately 30 cm above the bowl's surface to minimize splashing.

Immediately, using the same spatula, begin gently stirring the water and dry yeast mixture in a circular motion. Continue stirring for exactly 30 seconds, maintaining a consistent speed and pressure. Do not stir too vigorously, as this can damage the yeast.

Visually inspect the mixture. The dry yeast mixture should be fully incorporated into the water. There should be no visible clumps of dry yeast remaining. If clumps persist, gently stir for an additional 10 seconds, maintaining the consistent stirring motion.
Allow Dough to Bloom: Let the dough rest for 5-10 minutes.

Locate the Dough Bowl: Identify the ceramic or stainless steel bowl in which the dough is currently resting. Ensure the bowl's interior surface is clean and dry. Visually confirm that the bowl's diameter is precisely 20 centimeters (7.87 inches).

Prepare the Resting Surface: Obtain a clean, dry cloth – preferably linen or cotton – measuring 30 centimeters by 30 centimeters (11.81 inches by 11.81 inches). Lay the cloth flat on a stable surface, ensuring it is positioned no more than 5 centimeters (1.97 inches) away from the edge of the work surface.

Transfer the Dough: Using a spatula or bench scraper with a blade length of 15 centimeters (5.91 inches), gently lift the dough from its original container. Maintain a consistent height of 2 centimeters (0.79 inches) above the dough's surface to minimize contact and deflation. Slowly slide the spatula under the dough, ensuring complete removal from the original container.

Position the Dough: Carefully center the transferred dough onto the prepared cloth. Adjust the dough's position so that the center of the dough is exactly 10 centimeters (3.94 inches) from the center of the cloth. Maintain this spatial relationship throughout the resting period.

Initial Observation: Using a digital stopwatch, initiate the timing. Observe the dough for exactly 30 seconds. During this period, visually note the dough's texture - specifically, the degree of slackness or elasticity. Record this observation in a small notepad with a precise time stamp (MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS).

Resting Period - Phase 1 (Minutes 1-5): Begin timing again with the stopwatch. The dough should remain undisturbed. Do not touch, move, or rotate the dough. Maintain a consistent visual check every 60 seconds, noting any subtle changes in texture, volume, or surface characteristics. Record observations as above.

Resting Period - Phase 2 (Minutes 6-10): Continue timing with the stopwatch. Maintain undisturbed rest. Conduct a visual inspection every 60 seconds, recording observations using the same time and note-taking procedure as before.

Final Observation: At the 10-minute mark, stop the stopwatch. Carefully examine the dough one last time, noting its final texture and any changes that occurred during the resting process. Record this final observation.
Cover Dough: Place a damp cloth over the dough to prevent drying.

Locate the Dough: Identify the prepared dough, ensuring it is within reach – no more than 30 centimeters from your current working position. Observe the dough’s surface; it should appear slightly sticky and have a uniform texture. Confirm the dough is resting on a lightly floured surface, approximately 20 centimeters by 20 centimeters.

Retrieve the Cloth: Obtain a clean, lint-free cotton cloth. The cloth must be rectangular, measuring 40 centimeters by 40 centimeters. Ensure the cloth is folded in half lengthwise, creating a 20 centimeter by 40 centimeter rectangle. Place the folded cloth on a stable surface directly adjacent to the dough, maintaining a distance of 15 centimeters.

Position the Cloth: Carefully unfold the cloth, ensuring it lies flat on the surface. Align one of the 40 centimeter edges of the cloth with the nearest edge of the dough, maintaining a gap of exactly 2.5 centimeters between the cloth’s edge and the dough’s edge. This gap must be maintained consistently throughout the process.

Drape the Cloth: Using your right hand, gently lift one of the 40 centimeter sides of the cloth. With a smooth, deliberate motion, bring the lifted side down over the dough, ensuring the entire surface of the dough is covered. Maintain a downward trajectory of approximately 30 degrees. The cloth should drape evenly across the dough. Do not allow the cloth to overlap the dough's edges by more than 1 centimeter.

Secure the Overhang (Optional): If the overhang exceeds 1 centimeter, using your left hand, gently pull the overhanging section of the cloth closer to the dough. This action should be smooth and controlled, preventing any tearing or pulling of the cloth. Maintain a consistent tension across the cloth.

Verify Coverage: Visually inspect the entire surface of the dough. Confirm that at least 95% of the dough's surface is covered by the cloth. Note any exposed areas and adjust the cloth’s position as needed.

Maintain Tension: Gently apply slight upward pressure on the cloth with your hands, ensuring it remains in contact with the dough. This should be a uniform pressure across the entire covered surface. Do not apply excessive force.

Stabilize Position: Ensure the cloth remains stationary. Avoid any sudden movements or vibrations that could disturb the dough's surface or the cloth's position. Maintain this position for a minimum of 60 seconds.
Monitor Dough Rise: Observe the dough for signs of rising (e.g., volume increase, bubbles).
Position yourself directly in front of the dough container, maintaining a distance of precisely 30 centimeters from the container's rim. Ensure your eyes are level with the top surface of the dough.

Using a standard ruler with millimeter markings, measure the vertical height of the dough from the bottom of the container to the highest point of the dough. Record this measurement in centimeters. Note this as the 'Initial Height'.

Using a digital camera with a resolution of at least 1920x1080 pixels, capture a still image of the dough. Focus the camera on the center of the dough. Ensure the image is completely in focus and has a sharp detail.
Allow 60 seconds to elapse. During this time, maintain the 30-centimeter distance and continue to observe the dough. Do not adjust your position or the camera's angle.
Repeat the measurement of the dough's vertical height from the container bottom to the highest point. Record this as the 'After 60 Seconds Height'.
Visually inspect the dough for the presence of bubbles. Count the number of visible bubbles larger than 2 millimeters in diameter. Record this as 'Bubble Count'.
Repeat the 60-second observation period. Record the 'After 120 Seconds Height' measurement.
Repeat the bubble count procedure, recording the 'After 120 Seconds Bubble Count'.
Repeat the entire observation and measurement process for a total observation period of 180 seconds.
Analyze the recorded data: Compare the 'Initial Height' to the 'After 180 Seconds Height'. Calculate the percentage change in volume. Assess the change in bubble count over the 180-second period.
Shape Dough
Prepare Dough Surface

Locate the rolling pin. Ensure the rolling pin is clean and dry. Confirm the diameter of the rolling pin is precisely 4.5 inches (11.43 cm). Visually inspect the rolling pin surface for any imperfections or residue. If any are detected, gently wipe the surface with a lint-free microfiber cloth dampened with distilled water.

Retrieve a clean, dry work surface. Select a silicone baking mat measuring 12 inches x 18 inches (30.48 cm x 45.72 cm). Place the mat centered on a sturdy, clean countertop. Confirm the mat is free of any debris or crumbs. If any are present, carefully sweep the surface with a soft-bristled brush.

Position the dough ball. Take a ball of dough approximately 8 ounces (226.8 grams) in weight. Gently lift the dough ball, supporting it evenly from all sides to maintain its shape. Hold the dough ball approximately 6 inches (15.24 cm) above the silicone mat.

Initiate the first roll. Using the rolling pin, begin applying downward pressure. Starting at the center of the dough ball, roll outwards in a smooth, consistent circular motion. Maintain a pressure level that is gentle but firm, approximately 15 pounds (6.8 kg) of consistent force. Roll for a duration of precisely 3 seconds.

Rotate the dough. After the 3-second roll, rotate the dough by 90 degrees clockwise. Maintain the same consistent rolling pressure – approximately 15 pounds (6.8 kg). Continue rolling for another 3 seconds.
Repeat Rotation and Rolling. Rotate the dough 90 degrees clockwise again. Roll for 3 seconds, maintaining consistent pressure.
Repeat Rotation and Rolling. Rotate the dough 90 degrees clockwise. Roll for 3 seconds, maintaining consistent pressure.

Final Shaping – Diameter Confirmation. Continue rolling the dough in 90-degree increments, rolling for 3 seconds each time. After completing four full rotations (360 degrees), assess the diameter of the dough circle. Using a ruler, measure the diameter. The diameter should be between 8.5 and 9 inches (21.59 cm - 22.86 cm). If the diameter is outside this range, adjust your rolling pressure slightly and repeat the process. Ensure the dough is evenly distributed and free from any cracks or tears.

Surface Smoothing (Optional). If a perfectly smooth surface is desired, gently drag a silicone spatula across the surface of the dough, applying light pressure. Maintain a speed of approximately 2 inches per second.
Divide Dough into Portions

Locate the Dough Container: Identify the plastic container holding the dough. Ensure it is resting on a stable, level surface, free from any vibration or movement. The surface should be clean and dry.

Measure Container Diameter: Using a calibrated measuring tape, precisely measure the diameter of the container's opening. Record this measurement in millimeters. Maintain the measuring tape taut and level throughout the measurement. Record the measurement as 225.0 mm ± 0.1 mm.

Prepare Cutting Utensil: Retrieve a clean, dry, stainless steel pastry cutter, approximately 18 centimeters in length. Verify the blade is sharp and free of any debris or grease. Place the cutter on a clean, dry work surface.

Initial Dough Placement: Gently slide approximately 300 grams of dough from the container onto the work surface. Ensure the entire mass of dough is spread evenly across the work surface, covering an area of 15 cm x 15 cm.

First Cutting Motion (Phase 1): With your right hand firmly supporting the dough, begin a cutting motion with the pastry cutter. Starting 5 mm above the work surface, apply a downward pressure of 2.5 Newtons. Move the cutter in a smooth, continuous circular motion, covering a 90-degree arc, for a duration of 1.2 seconds. Maintain a cutter speed of 15 cm per second.

First Cutting Motion (Phase 2): Repeat the previous cutting motion, again starting 5 mm above the work surface, for a duration of 1.2 seconds. Maintain a cutter speed of 15 cm per second. Ensure the cut is clean and distinct, with no tearing of the dough.

Second Cutting Motion: With your right hand firmly supporting the dough, begin a cutting motion with the pastry cutter. Starting 5 mm above the work surface, apply a downward pressure of 2.5 Newtons. Move the cutter in a smooth, continuous circular motion, covering a 90-degree arc, for a duration of 1.2 seconds. Maintain a cutter speed of 15 cm per second.

Final Dough Division: Continue the cutting motion, applying downward pressure of 2.5 Newtons, rotating the cutter 90 degrees, and repeating the 1.2-second cut until the entire mass of dough is divided into approximately 8 equal portions. Visually inspect each portion for approximate equal size.

Portion Adjustment (Optional): Using a kitchen scale, measure the weight of each portion. If any portion deviates by more than 5 grams from the average weight, gently re-shape the portion and repeat the cutting process.  Ensure the total weight of the divided dough is within 10 grams of 300 grams.
Dough Container Resumption: Carefully slide the divided portions back into the original container.  Ensure all pieces are completely contained within the container.  Close the container lid securely.
Press Dough into Desired Shape
Locate the Dough Ball: Using your dominant hand, identify the central point of the dough ball. This point should be approximately 2.5 centimeters (1 inch) from the top surface of the dough.

Initial Palm Contact: With your dominant hand, bring your palm directly upwards towards the center of the dough ball. Ensure your palm is perpendicular to the surface of the dough. Apply gentle, even pressure – approximately 5 Newtons (1.12 lbs) – to begin flattening the dough.

Circular Motion - Phase 1: Starting from the initial contact point, begin a clockwise circular motion with your palm. Maintain a radius of 8 centimeters (3.15 inches) from the center. Execute this motion for precisely 3 seconds. Maintain a constant speed – approximately 1 revolution per second.

Pause & Assessment: After the 3-second circular motion, cease all movement. Observe the dough. Note the thickness of the flattened area – it should be approximately 1.0 centimeter (0.4 inches) thick. If the thickness is outside this range, adjust your subsequent movements accordingly.

Circular Motion - Phase 2: With your dominant hand, repeat the clockwise circular motion, this time using a radius of 12 centimeters (4.72 inches). Maintain the same 3-second duration and approximately 1 revolution per second speed. The center of the circle should remain precisely over the original contact point.

Stabilization & Edge Refinement: After the second 3-second circular motion, pause. Using only your fingertips of your dominant hand, gently push outwards from the edges of the flattened dough. Extend each finger approximately 3 centimeters (1.18 inches) from the perimeter. Apply a gentle, upward pressure of 2 Newtons (0.45 lbs) per finger. Repeat this outward push for 1.5 seconds, maintaining a constant arc.

Final Shape Assessment: Rotate the dough slowly with your dominant hand, observing the overall shape. Identify any uneven areas or irregularities. Note the target shape (e.g., circle, square, triangle). Ensure the overall diameter or length of the shape is within +/- 0.5 centimeter (0.2 inches) of the desired value.

Gentle Smoothing: Using your fingertips, gently smooth the surface of the dough, paying particular attention to the edges. Apply a very light, circular motion with your fingertips, covering a radius of 5 centimeters (1.97 inches). Execute this smoothing motion for 2 seconds.
Roll Out Dough to Thickness

Locate the rolling pin and ensure it is clean and dry. Verify the rolling pin's length is 18 inches (45.72 cm) and its diameter is 2.5 inches (6.35 cm) at its widest point. Place the rolling pin on a stable, flat surface, approximately 12 inches (30.48 cm) from the center of the dough.

Retrieve a rectangular sheet of dough approximately 12 inches (30.48 cm) by 18 inches (45.72 cm) and 1/4 inch (0.635 cm) thick. Position the dough centered on a lightly floured work surface. Ensure the floured surface is a standard wooden cutting board, 20 inches (50.8 cm) long and 12 inches (30.48 cm) wide.

Using your right hand, gently grasp the dough at one of its 12-inch (30.48 cm) edges. Lift the dough slightly, approximately 0.5 inches (1.27 cm) off the work surface. Maintain constant, light pressure.

With your left hand, grasp the rolling pin at its mid-point. Position the rolling pin so the handle is aligned with the 18-inch (45.72 cm) side of the dough. Maintain a 30-degree angle between the rolling pin and the dough surface.

Begin rolling the dough with a slow, deliberate motion. Apply a consistent pressure, approximately 5 pounds (2.27 kg), measured using a calibrated kitchen scale. Roll the dough in a straight line, maintaining the 30-degree angle. Cover approximately 6 inches (15.24 cm) of the dough with each roll.

Maintain this rolling motion for 3 seconds, covering a total distance of 18 inches (45.72 cm) along the 18-inch (45.72 cm) side. Observe the dough's surface; it should remain relatively smooth and even. If any creases or tears appear, reduce pressure slightly and slow down the rolling speed.

Shift the dough slightly – approximately 6 inches (15.24 cm) to the right – maintaining the 30-degree angle and consistent pressure. Continue rolling for another 3 seconds, covering an additional 18 inches (45.72 cm).

Repeat this rolling motion – 3 seconds per 18-inch (45.72 cm) section – until the entire 12 inches (30.48 cm) by 18 inches (45.72 cm) sheet of dough is rolled out to a uniform thickness of 1/4 inch (0.635 cm).
Once the rolling is complete, gently lift the rolled dough with your right hand and place it onto a clean, flat surface, approximately 6 inches (15.24 cm) from the edge of the cutting board.
