Observe Dough for Increased Volume
Position yourself 1.5 meters directly to the right of the proofing vessel. Ensure your dominant eye is focused on the center of the dough’s surface.
Using a digital caliper, measure the diameter of the dough at its widest point. Record this measurement in millimeters. Verify the measurement is within a tolerance of +/- 1 millimeter.

Using a laser pointer, establish a point of reference at the exact center of the dough’s surface. Maintain this laser point consistently throughout the observation process. The laser should be held at a 45-degree angle relative to the dough's surface.

Using a smartphone camera with a 12MP sensor, position the camera 30 centimeters directly above the laser point, ensuring the camera lens is perpendicular to the dough’s surface. Activate the camera’s grid overlay for precise alignment.

Take a still photograph of the dough, focusing on the area within a 5-centimeter radius of the laser point. Ensure the image is sharp and the color is accurately represented. Save the image as 'Dough_Volume_Observation_1'. Verify the image resolution is 12 megapixels.
Move the camera 10 centimeters to the left, maintaining the same 10-degree angle relative to the dough's surface. Repeat the photograph-taking process. Save the image as 'Dough_Volume_Observation_2'.
Repeat the previous step, moving the camera an additional 10 centimeters to the left. Save the image as 'Dough_Volume_Observation_3'.
Repeat the previous step, resulting in a total horizontal displacement of 30 centimeters from the initial position. Save the image as 'Dough_Volume_Observation_4'.

Analyze the four photographs. Using a scale provided in pixels per millimeter (determined during calibration – 1 pixel = 0.05mm), estimate the diameter of the dough in each photograph. Record the diameter in millimeters for each image. Calculate the average diameter.

Calculate the volume of the dough using the formula for a sphere (V = (4/3)πr³) with the average diameter used as the radius. Report the calculated volume in cubic centimeters. Round the result to the nearest 0.1 cubic centimeter.
Check Dough Texture for Bubbles

Locate the Dough: Using your right hand, reach forward and grasp the mixing bowl with your fingertips, ensuring a firm but gentle hold. Your fingertips should cover approximately 75% of the bowl's diameter – a radius of 18.75 centimeters is the target. Maintain this grip throughout the following steps.

Visual Inspection – Initial Assessment: Slowly rotate the bowl, 90 degrees clockwise, with your left hand, maintaining a constant speed of 2 revolutions per second. During this rotation, observe the surface of the dough, focusing your gaze on a 15-degree arc starting 30 centimeters from the center of the bowl and ending 60 centimeters from the center. Note the presence or absence of bubbles.

Probe with Index Finger: Using only your right index finger, gently poke the dough at precisely 10 points, spaced 15 centimeters apart in a circular pattern extending from the bowl’s center to the outer edge. Each poke should involve a downward motion of 2.5 centimeters in depth. Record the immediate response of the dough at each point – whether it springs back immediately, remains slightly indented, or collapses.

Bubble Identification – Magnified View: Utilize a magnifying glass with a magnification of 10x. Position the magnifying glass 5 centimeters above the dough's surface. Slowly move the magnifying glass in a circular motion, covering a 30-degree arc centered on a point 40 centimeters from the bowl’s center. Document the size and number of bubbles detected. Each bubble should be clearly visible against the dough’s surface. The diameter of a recorded bubble must be between 2mm and 5mm.

Surface Tension Measurement – Hand Contact: With your right index finger, lightly touch the dough surface at five randomly selected points, ensuring each point has a contact time of 0.5 seconds. Note the immediate effect on the dough, specifically the degree of surface displacement. A displacement greater than 0.8mm is considered a high-pressure indicator.

Repeat Probe at Initial Points: Return to the five initial probe points established in Step 4. Using the same probe depth (2.5cm), record the presence or absence of bubble formation after a 1-second delay. Document the dough's surface texture following each poke. Measure the surface indentation depth after each probe. Note the texture change – observe if the indentation persists or disappears.

Overall Texture Assessment: Visually assess the overall texture of the dough, noting any areas of excessive air pockets, uneven surface, or inconsistencies in elasticity. Record the overall texture rating on a scale of 1-5, with 1 being excessively bubbly and 5 being smooth and uniform. Use a consistent visual reference point throughout the assessment.

Final Documentation: Record all observations – bubble size, number, location, and the overall dough texture – in a designated notebook or digital recording, noting the time of observation and the temperature of the dough.
Assess Dough Rise Rate

Initial Observation: Locate the dough in its mixing bowl. The bowl's diameter shall be measured using a flexible measuring tape, with the tape placed precisely along the inner circumference of the bowl. Record this measurement as 'Bowl Diameter' - 28.3 centimeters. Note the dough's initial height from the bowl's bottom, measuring this height with a digital caliper, recording it as 'Initial Dough Height' - 3.7 centimeters. Observe the dough’s consistency visually, noting any large air bubbles or inconsistencies. Record this initial visual assessment as 'Initial Dough Condition' - ‘Smooth, minimal bubbles’.

Timer Activation: Activate a digital stopwatch. Set the stopwatch to a 60-second interval. Confirm the stopwatch is displaying '00:00:00' with a clear, visible countdown. Ensure the stopwatch's button is easily accessible and responsive.

Heat Source Activation: Position a heat source (e.g., a heating element, a pre-warmed surface) precisely 15 centimeters above the mixing bowl. Ensure the heat source is stable and does not vibrate excessively. Verify the distance remains constant throughout the observation period.

Dough Placement: Carefully lift the mixing bowl with both hands, maintaining a firm grip. Slowly lower the bowl directly above the heat source, maintaining a vertical alignment. Lower the bowl to a height of 5 centimeters above the heat source. Hold the bowl stationary for 3 seconds, preventing any sudden movements.

Observation Interval 1: Begin recording the rise rate. Using a high-resolution digital camera with a fixed focus, capture a photograph of the dough every 10 seconds for the next 60 seconds. Ensure the camera is positioned at a fixed distance of 30 centimeters directly above the center of the dough. Frame the image to include the entire surface of the dough.

Measurement Calculation - Rise Rate (Second Interval): After the 10-second interval, using the photograph, measure the new height of the dough in the same manner as the 'Initial Dough Height' – 3.7 centimeters. Calculate the rise in height (ΔH) using the formula: ΔH = New Dough Height – Initial Dough Height. Record this value as 'Rise Rate – Interval 1' - 0.3 centimeters per 10 seconds.

Observation Interval 2: Repeat the observation interval of 10 seconds every 10 seconds for a total of 60 seconds. Capture a new photograph of the dough every 10 seconds using the same camera settings and measurements as in Observation Interval 1.

Measurement Calculation – Rise Rate (Final): After the 60 seconds, analyze the recorded photographs. Determine the total rise in height (ΔH_Total) by calculating the difference in height between the first and last photographs. Record this total rise as 'Total Rise Rate' - 3.3 centimeters.

Data Recording: Log all measurements (Bowl Diameter, Initial Dough Height, Rise Rate – Interval 1, Total Rise Rate) into a digital spreadsheet. Ensure each measurement is accurately recorded with associated timestamps.

Equipment Shutdown: Power off the digital stopwatch and the heat source. Ensure the heat source is completely disconnected from its power source. Return all equipment to its designated storage location.
Note Dough Height and Shape

Locate the Dough: Using your right hand, extend your arm fully, aligning your wrist with the center of the dough. Maintain a 90-degree angle at your elbow. Ensure your fingers are relaxed and not actively pushing against the dough.

Establish a Reference Point: With your left hand, position your index finger directly above the center of the dough. Maintain this position stationary for the next 3 seconds. Do not move your hand or finger.

Visual Alignment: Keeping your left hand in place, slowly bring your right hand, with the dough, towards the reference point established by your left hand. Maintain a constant speed of 1 centimeter per second. Do not accelerate or decelerate.

Height Measurement – Initial Observation: Upon reaching a distance of 20 centimeters from the reference point, pause your movement. Observe the top surface of the dough. Note the vertical distance, measured from the base of the dough to the highest point of the surface, using your left eye. Estimate this distance to within 1 millimeter. Record this value (Height 1).

Shape Assessment – Lateral Observation: With your right hand, slowly rotate your hand clockwise by 45 degrees. Maintain the same distance of 20 centimeters from the reference point. Observe the shape of the dough's lateral profile. Note the widest point of the dough's surface, measuring from left to right, using your left eye. Record this measurement (Width 1) in millimeters.

Rotation Return: Slowly rotate your hand back to the original position, aligning your right hand with the reference point and the initial height. Maintain a speed of 1 centimeter per second. This should take approximately 3 seconds.

Height Measurement – Second Observation: Upon reaching the original alignment, pause your movement. Observe the top surface of the dough. Note the vertical distance, measured from the base of the dough to the highest point of the surface, using your left eye. Record this value (Height 2) in millimeters. Ensure the measurement is within +/- 0.5 millimeters of Height 1.

Shape Assessment – Longitudinal Observation: With your right hand, slowly rotate your hand counter-clockwise by 45 degrees. Maintain a distance of 20 centimeters from the reference point. Observe the shape of the dough's lateral profile. Note the longest point of the dough’s surface, measuring from front to back, using your left eye. Record this measurement (Length 1) in millimeters.

Final Alignment & Confirmation: Slowly return your hand to the initial alignment, maintaining a 90-degree angle at your elbow. Verify that the dough is positioned exactly as observed during the previous measurements. Take one final visual check, noting the overall shape and confirming all recorded measurements.
Determine if Second Rise is Complete

Locate the designated 'Second Rise' marker. This marker is a small, circular, red plastic disc affixed to the north-facing wall of the fermentation chamber. Ensure the marker is precisely 1.75 meters from the base of the central fermentation tank. Use a laser distance measurer to verify this distance to within a tolerance of +/- 2mm. Record this distance in centimeters in a digital note.

Using a calibrated digital thermometer, measure the temperature at the surface of the rising dough within the fermentation chamber. Maintain a stable measurement for 15 seconds before recording. Record the temperature in degrees Celsius to one decimal place. Note the exact time (HH:MM:SS) at which the temperature is recorded.

Visually inspect the dough. Confirm the dough has risen at least 50% of its original volume. Measure the current diameter of the risen dough column, using a flexible measuring tape. Record this diameter in millimeters. Ensure the tape is held taut and perpendicular to the dough surface.

Measure the original volume of the dough. Using a graduated cylinder of exactly 250ml capacity, carefully scoop the initial dough from the fermentation chamber. Ensure no dough adheres to the sides of the cylinder. Record the exact volume of dough in milliliters.

Calculate the percentage increase in volume. Divide the current volume (from step 5) by the original volume (from step 5). Express the result as a percentage. Record this percentage to one decimal place.

Check the doming. Measure the maximum height of the risen dough column using the same flexible measuring tape used in step 4. Record this height in millimeters. The height must be at least 80mm to be considered complete.

Record your final determination. Based on all measurements and observations, state definitively whether ‘Second Rise’ is complete. Record this as ‘Complete’ or ‘Incomplete’ in a digital note. Include all recorded measurements and the time of the assessment (HH:MM:SS).
